article.title: Apollo_9

template.arg: David Scott performs an EVA from Command Module ''Gumdrop'', seen from docked Lunar Module ''Spider''

[[Apollo Command/Service Module|Apollo CSM]]-104
[[Apollo Lunar Module|Apollo LM]]-3

[[David Scott|David R. Scott]]

article.paragraph: Apollo 9was the third manned mission in theUnited StatesApollo programApollo space programand the first flight of theApollo Command/Service ModuleCommand/Service Module(CSM) with theApollo Lunar ModuleLunar Module(LM). Its three-person crew, consisting of CommanderJames McDivitt, Command Module PilotDavid Scott, and Lunar Module PilotRusty Schweickart, spent ten days inlow Earth orbittesting several aspects critical to landing on the Moon, including the LM engines, backpack life support systems, navigation systems, and docking maneuvers. The mission was the second manned launch of aSaturn Vrocket.

After launching on March 3, 1969, the crewmen performed the first manned flight of a LM, the first docking and extraction of a LM, twoExtra-vehicular activityspacewalks(EVA), and the second docking of two mannedspacecrafttwo months after theSoviet UnionSovietsperformed a spacewalk crew transfer betweenSoyuz 4andSoyuz 5. The mission proved the LM worthy of manned spaceflight. Further tests on theApollo 10mission would prepare the LM for its ultimate goal, landing on the Moon. They returned to Earth on March 13, 1969.
article.heading: Crew
Backup crew
article.paragraph: Spaceflight crewAstronaut Commander [[Pete Conrad|Charles Conrad, Jr]], Command Module Pilot [[Richard F. Gordon, Jr.]] Lunar Module Pilot [[Alan Bean|Alan L. Bean]] The backup crew became the prime crew on [[Apollo 12]]. Clifton Williamswas the original backup Lunar Module Pilot on Conrad's crew, but was killed in October 1967 when theNorthrop T-38 TalonT-38he was flying crashed nearTallahassee.

article.heading: Mission background
article.paragraph: File:McDivitt, Scott and Schweickart in preliminary training for Apollo AS-258 mission.jpgthumbMcDivitt, Scott and Schweickart train for the AS-258 mission in the first block II Command Module, wearing early versions of the block II pressure suitIn April 1966, McDivitt, Scott, and Schweickart were selected by Deke Slayton as the second Apollo crew, as backup toGus Grissom,Edward Higgins WhiteEd White, andRoger Chaffeefor the first manned Earth orbital test flight of theApollo Command/Service Module#Development historyblock I Command/Service Module,cite news'Open End' Orbit Planned for Apollohttp://news.google.com/newspapers?idUnited Press International[[Pittsburgh Press|The Pittsburgh Press]]Pittsburgh, PAAugust 4, 196620November 11, 2010designatedApollo 1AS-204expected to fly in late 1966. This was to be followed by a second block I flight,AS-205, to be crewed byWally Schirra,Donn F. EiseleDonn Eisele, andWalter Cunningham. The third manned mission, designated AS-207/208, was planned to fly the block II Command Module and theApollo Lunar ModuleLunar Modulein Earth orbit, launched on separateSaturn IBs, with a crew to be named.

However, delays in the block I CSM development pushed AS-204 into 1967. By December 1966, the original AS-205 mission was cancelled, Schirra's crew was named as Grissom's backup, and McDivitt's crew was promoted to prime crew for the LM test mission,cite bookBrooksCourtney G.GrimwoodJames M.SwensonLoyd S., Jr.Foreword by [[Samuel C. Phillips]]Chariots for Apollo: A History of Manned Lunar Spacecrafthttp://history.nasa.gov/SP-4205/cover.htmlJanuary 29, 2008NASA History Series1979Scientific and Technical Information Branch, NASAWashington, D.C.0-486-46756-24664449NASA SP-4205Preparations for the First Manned Apollo Missionhttp://www.hq.nasa.gov/office/pao/History/SP-4205/ch8-7.htmlre-designatedAS-205/208. On January 26, 1967, they were training for this flight, expected to occur in late 1967, in the first block II Command Module 101 at theNorth American AviationNorth Americanplant inDowney, California.cite webApollo Image Gallery: Early ApolloProject Apollo ArchiveKipp Teaguehttp://www.apolloarchive.com/apollo_gallery.htmlAugust 3, 2010The next day, Grissom's crew were conducting a launch-pad test for their planned February 21 mission, which they namedApollo 1, when a fire broke out in the cabin, killing all three men and putting an 18-month hold on the manned program while the block IIApollo Command/Service Module#Command Module (CM)Command Module(CM) andApollo/Skylab A7LA7L pressure suitwere redesigned for safety.

As it turned out, a 1967 launch of AS-205/208 would have been impossible even absent the Apollo 1 accident, as problems with the LM delayed its first unmanned test flight until January 1968. NASA was able to use the 18-month hiatus to catch up with development and unmanned testing of the LM and the Saturn V launch vehicle.cite bookBrooksCourtney G.GrimwoodJames M.SwensonLoyd S., Jr.Foreword by [[Samuel C. Phillips]]Chariots for Apollo: A History of Manned Lunar Spacecrafthttp://history.nasa.gov/SP-4205/cover.htmlJanuary 29, 2008NASA History Series1979Scientific and Technical Information Branch, NASAWashington, D.C.0-486-46756-24664449NASA SP-4205''Apollo 5'': The Lunar Module's Debuthttp://www.hq.nasa.gov/office/pao/History/SP-4205/ch10-3.html

By October 1967, planning for manned flights resumed, withApollo 7being the first Earth orbit CSM flight (now known as theC mission) in October 1968 given to Schirra's crew, and McDivitt's mission (now known as theD Mission) following as Apollo 8 in December 1968, using a single Saturn V instead of the two Saturn IBs. This would be followed by a higher Earth orbit flight (E Mission), to be crewed byFrank Borman,Michael Collins (astronaut)Michael Collins, andWilliam Andersin early 1969.

However, LM problems again prevented it from being ready for the D mission by December, so NASA officials created another mission forApollo 8using the Saturn V to launch only the CSM on the first manned flight to orbit the Moon, and the E mission was cancelled as unnecessary. Slayton asked McDivitt and Borman which mission they preferred to fly; McDivitt wanted to fly the LM, while Borman volunteered for the pioneering lunar flight. Therefore Slayton swapped the crews, and McDivitt's crew flew Apollo 9.

The crew swap also affected who would be the first crew to land on the Moon; when the crews for Apollo 8 and 9 were swapped, their backup crews were also swapped. Since the rule of thumb was for backup crews to fly as prime crew three missions later, this putNeil Armstrong's crew (Borman's backup) in position for the first landing missionApollo 11instead ofPete Conrad's crew, who made the second landing onApollo 12.
article.heading: Mission highlights

link.part: Apollo 9 launches fromKennedy Space Center, March 3, 1969

article.paragraph: Apollo 9 was the first space test of the complete Apollo spacecraft, including the third critical piece of Apollo hardware besides the Command/Service Module and the Saturn V launch vehiclethe Lunar Module. It was also the firstspace rendezvousspace dockingof two vehicles with an internal crew transfer between them. For ten days, the astronauts put both Apollo spacecraft through their paces in Earth orbit, including an undocking and redocking of the lunar lander with the command vehicle, just as the landing mission crew would perform in lunar orbit. Apollo 9 gave proof that the Apollo spacecraft were up to this critical task, on which the lives of lunar landing crews would depend.

For this and all subsequent Apollo flights, the crews were allowed to name their own spacecraft (the last spacecraft to have been named wasGemini 3). The gangly LM was namedSpider, and the CSM was labeledGumdropbecause of the Command Module's shape, and also the blue wrapping in which the craft arrived atKennedy Space Center. These names were required as radio call signs when the vehicles flew independently.

Schweickart and Scott performed an EVASchweickart checked out the newApollo/Skylab A7LApollo spacesuit, the first to have its own life support system rather than being dependent on an umbilical connection to the spacecraft, while Scott filmed him from the Command Module hatch. Schweickart was due to carry out a more extensive set of activities to test the suit, and demonstrate that it was possible for astronauts to perform an EVA from the Lunar Module to the Command Module in an emergency, but as he had been suffering fromSpace adaptation syndromespace sicknessthe extra tests were scratched.

link.part: Apollo 9 approachessplashdown (spacecraft landing)splashdownin theAtlantic Ocean, March 13, 1969

article.paragraph: McDivitt and Schweickart later test-flew the LM, and practiced separation and docking maneuvers in Earth orbit. They flew the LM up toconvert111mikmfromGumdrop, using the engine on the descent stage to propel them originally, before jettisoning it and using the ascent stage to return. This test flight represented the first flight of a manned spacecraft that was not equipped to reenter the Earth's atmosphere.

The splashdown point was 23 deg 15 min N, 67 deg 56 min W, 180 miles (290 km) east ofthe Bahamasand within sight of the recovery shipUSS Guadalcanal (LPH-7)USS ''Guadalcanal''. Apollo 9 was the last spacecraft to splash down in the Atlantic Ocean.

The Command Module was displayed at the Michigan Space and Science Center,Jackson, Michigan, until April 2004 when the center closed.Citation neededJune 2013In May 2004, it was moved to theSan Diego Air & Space MuseumSan Diego Aerospace Museum(now named the San Diego Air & Space Museum). The LM ascent stage orbit decayed on October 23, 1981, the LM descent stage (1969-018D) orbit decayed March 22, 1969. TheS-IVBstageJ-2 (rocket engine)J-2engine was restarted after Lunar Module extraction and propelled the stage into solar orbit by burning to depletion.

TheS-IVBSaturn IVBthird stagebecame a:Category:Derelict satellites in heliocentric orbitderelictspace debrisobjectwhere it would continue toheliocentric orbitorbit the Sunfor many years.asof201411, it remains in orbit.cite webSaturn S-IVB-504N - Satellite Informationhttp://www.heavens-above.com/SatInfo.aspx?satidSatellite databaseHeavens-AboveSeptember 23, 2013
article.heading: Mission insignia
article.paragraph: File:Apollo 9 Flown Silver Robbins Medallion (SN-260).jpgthumbApollo 9 space-flown silverNASA space-flown Robbins medallions of the Apollo missionsRobbins medallionThe circular patch shows a drawing of a Saturn V rocket with the letters USA on it. To its right, an Apollo CSM is shown next to an LM, with the CSM's nose pointed at the "front door" of the LM rather than at its top docking port. The CSM is trailing rocket fire in a circle. The crew's names are along the top edge of the circle, with APOLLORoman numeralsIXat the bottom. The "D" in McDivitt's name is filled with red to mark that this was the "D mission" in the alphabetic sequence of Apollo missions. The patch was designed by Allen Stevens ofRockwell International.cite webEdHengeveldhttp://www.collectspace.com/news/news-052008a.htmlThe man behind the Moon mission patchescollectSPACEMay 20, 2008July 18, 2009"A version of this article was published concurrently in theBritish Interplanetary Society'sSpaceflight (magazine)Spaceflightmagazine."

article.heading: Spacecraft location
article.paragraph: The Apollo 9 Command ModuleGumdrop(1969-018A) is on display at theSan Diego Air & Space Museum,San DiegoSan Diego, California. ItsApollo Command/Service Module#Service Module (SM)Service Module(SM) was jettisoned shortly after the deorbit burn and decayed during reentry of the Command Module.
The ascent stage of LM-3Spider(1969-018C) decayed on October 23, 1981.cite webApollo 9http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?idNational Space Science Data CenterNASAApril 7, 2014
The descent stage of LM-3Spider(1969-018D) decayed March 22, 1969.
The upper stage of the Apollo 9 Saturn V, S-IVB-504N, (1969-018B) remains inheliocentric orbitheliocentric(solar) orbitasof2014yes.
